title.narrative: Contribution to prog partners SAF region

description.narrative: This Southern African water management project focuses on the Limpopo River Basin. This river basin covers an area that is located in South Africa, Botswana, Zimbabwe and Mozambique. The program "One drop at a time - water for changing lives" took off late 2014. It was initiated from the awareness that Limpopo River Basin requires innovative climate resilient water management and water infrastructure systems that adequately support food production and livelihoods. The Limpopo Water Governance Program intends to research, design, develop, pilot, implement and scale up smart and innovative, climate resilient water management and water infrastructure systems for food security and climate resilient livelihoods, that are supported by local stakeholder inclusive water governance policies, institutions and systems at local, national, and regional levels. Key outcomes of this program include improved and inclusive access to the Limpopo basins water resources for food and agriculture as components of the climate resilient livelihood strategies of the rural population we are targeting. The program is part of Oxfam's global water governance program, which connects regional programs in Southern Africa (Limpopo river basin) and globally in Asia (Indus, Mekong, Salween, Ganges, Brahmaputra). The Oxfam Novib contribution will be used to further develop the program management <(>&<)> governance , as well as program networking with governmentaland regional institutions to increase the project's outreach.

participating-org.narrative: Oxfam International was formed in 1995 by a group of independent non-governmental organizations. Their aim was to work together forgreater impact on the international stage to reduce poverty and injustice. The name "Oxfam" comes from the Oxford Committee for Famine Relief, founded in Britain in 1942. The group campaigned for food supplies to be sent through an allied naval blockade to starving women and children in enemy-occupied Greece during the Second World War. As well as becoming a world leader in the delivery of emergency relief, Oxfam International implements long-term development programs in vulnerable communities. We are also part of a global movement, campaigning with others, for instance, to end unfair trade rules, demand better health and education services for all, and to combat climate change. Today, there are 19 member organizations of the Oxfam International confederation. They are based in: Australia, Belgium, Canada, Denmark, France, Germany, Great Britain, Hong Kong, Ireland, India, Italy, Japan, Mexico, The Netherlands, New Zealand, Quebec, South Africa, Spain and the United States. The Oxfam International Secretariat is based in Oxford, UK. The Secretariat runs advocacy offices in Addis Ababa, Brussels, Geneva, New York and Washington DC.

mailing-address.narrative: PO box 30919, 2500 GX The Hague, The Netherlands

sector.narrative: The right to a sustainable livelihood
